entry.title: Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts
entry.summary: A while back on CSS-Tricks, we shared several ways to draw hearts, and the response was dreamy. Now, to show my love, I wanted to do something personal, something crafty, something with a mild amount of effort. Handwriting an SVG Heart, With Our Hearts originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Scroll Driven Animations Notebook
entry.summary: Adamâ€™s such a mad scientist with CSS. Heâ€™s been putting together a series of â€œnotebooksâ€ that make it easy for him to demo code. Heâ€™s got one for gradient text, one for a comparison slider, another for accordionsâ€¦ Scroll Driven Animations Notebook originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. entry.title: Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS WithÂ tan(atan2())
entry.summary: Weâ€™ve been able to get the length of the viewport in CSS sinceâ€¦Â checks notesâ€¦Â 2013! Surprisingly, that was more than a decade ago. Getting the viewport width is as easy these days as easy as writingÂ 100vw, but â€¦ Typecasting and Viewport Transitions in CSS WithÂ tan(atan2()) originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers
entry.summary: I enjoy organizing code and find cascade layers a fantastic way to organize code explicitly as the cascade looks at it. The neat part is, that as much as it helps with "top-level" organization, cascade layers can be nested, which allows us to author more precise styles based on the cascade and inheritance. Organizing Design System Component Patterns With CSS Cascade Layers originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool
entry.summary: Stationery Pad is a handy way to nix a step in your workflow if you regularly use document templates on your Mac. The long-standing Finder feature essentially tells a fileâ€™s parent application to open a copy of it by default, ensuring that the original file remains unedited. Make Any File a Template Using This Hidden macOS Tool originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Chrome 133 Goodies
entry.summary: Did you see the release notes for Chrome 133? It's currently in beta, but the Chrome team has been publishing a slew of new articles with pretty incredible demos that are tough to ignore. I figured I'd round those up in one place. Chrome 133 Goodies originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running
entry.summary: When using View Transitions youâ€™ll notice the page becomes unresponsive to clicks while a View Transition is running. [â€¦] This happens because of theÂ ::view-transitionÂ pseudo element â€“ the one that contains all animated snapshots â€“ gets overlayed on top â€¦ Keeping the page interactive while a View Transition is running originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: The Mistakes of CSS
entry.summary: All of the things that the CSS Working Group would change if they had a time-traveling Delorean to go back and do things over. The Mistakes of CSS originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions?
entry.summary: The @view-transition at-rule has two descriptions. One is the commonly used navigation descriptor. The second is types, the lesser-known of the two, and one that probably envies how much attentionÂ navigationÂ gets. But read on to learn why we need types and how it opens up new possibilities for custom view transitions when navigating between pages. What on Earth is theÂ `types`Â Descriptor in View Transitions? originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

entry.title: Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset
entry.summary: When it comes to positioning elements on a page, including text, there are many ways to go about it in CSS â€” the literal position property with corresponding inset-* properties, translate, margin, anchor() (limited browser support at the moment), and so forth. The offset property is another one that belongs in that list. Positioning Text Around Elements With CSS Offset originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
